Comment: ICE did not have a judicial warrant for his arrest.  She told them to talk to the Chief of Court about getting one. They left, but did not get a warrant. The person they were their to arrest (illegally, because again, they did not have a warrant) left the building after the proceedings they were their for finished, and they seized him outside.  Given that they did not have a warrant for his arrest, categorically, they cannot argue the arrest was 'obstructed.'  The Supreme Court has already ruled, 9-0, that ICE *cannot* violate due process.
